awd_titl_txt: Study of Thermal Transport in Single Oligomer and Polymer Chains
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal goal of this research project is to experimentally study how heat is transported through single molecular chains. In contrast to bulk materials, researchers have only been able to make theoretical calculations regarding the flow heat through individual molecules, which include the surprising prediction that the resistance to heat flow is independent of the length of the molecule. Direct experimental measurements of the heat flow in single molecules have remained impossible due to the lack of appropriate instrumentation techniques to stably hold or confine single molecules and record the minute heat currents with sufficient resolution. In this proposal recent, groundbreaking experimental advances in picowatt-resolution calorimetry, high-resolution temperature measurements and experimental platforms will be used to tackle these challenging measurements with a systematic, experimental approach. In addition to the technical work, the proposal also incorporates extensive outreach activities to engage undergraduate and graduate students as well as underrepresented minorities in neighboring communities in research.

Thermal transport in single molecules and polymer chains, excellent approximations of one-dimensional systems, is of great current interest. Theoretical and computational studies, starting with Fermi, Pasta and Ulam in the 1950s, suggest that Fourier?s law is generally not valid for one-dimensional chains and imply the existence of a length-dependent, divergent thermal conductivity. To test these predictions detailed experimental measurements on single one-dimensional chains are essential to answer the following questions: What is the thermal conductance of single polymer molecules, how does it depend on the chain length and does the thermal conductivity diverge for all 1-dimensional systems? Can the thermal conductivity of single polymer molecules be modulated by changing the side groups? Can an exponential decrease in thermal conductance with increasing chain length be realized in custom-designed, disordered polymer chains?

por.por_cntn:
The principal goal of this research project was to experimentally characterize the thermal transport in one-dimensional (1D) organic molecular chains by directly recording the thermal conductance behavior of single molecule molecular junctions. The studies outlined for this proposal and subsequently carried out under the support of this support are critically important to advancing the field’s fundamental understanding of thermal transport processes, because they test central, theoretical predictions, including the hypothesis that Fourier’s Law will not be valid in the limit of momentum conserving 1D systems.

As a reference and a general introduction to the problem tackled in this work, let’s consider a bulk material that is made of polymers. Typically, such a material is thermally insulating and exhibits low thermal conductivities in the range of ~ 0.1 W/m·K. Given that the backbones of such polymers are made of molecules that feature strong covalent bonds, not too dissimilar to the carbon-carbon bonds in diamonds, it is superficially surprising that such materials are thermal insulators. The low thermal conductance can largely be understood by noting that most bulk polymers not only have weak interactions between individual molecules, but also feature many defects, including chain ends, voids, and impurities, which lead to phonon scattering. To understand the fundamental limits of the thermal properties of polymers it is essential to develop a systematic understanding of the thermal properties of polymers starting at the single molecule level. Intriguingly, a number of theoretical and computational studies, beginning with the early work by Fermi, Pasta and Ulam in the 1950s, have examined this question and come to the surprising conclusion that the thermal conductivity of one-dimensional chains depends on the chain length and is not size independent, in strong contrast to the thermal transport properties of bulk three-dimensional materials. In fact, these studies suggest that Fourier’s law, which relates the local heat current density in bulk materials to the gradients in the temperature field, is generally not valid for one-dimensional chains and imply the existence of a length-dependent, divergent thermal conductivity. Therefore, it is critical that detailed experimental measurements be conducted on single, one-dimensional molecular chains to determine what the conductance of a single molecule is and how the determine how the thermal conductance depends on the length of one-dimensional chains.

In terms of experimental work on single-molecule junctions we note that have been extensively used to probe a diverse range of properties, including their as electrical properties, light emission, thermoelectric energy conversion, quantum interference, heat dissipation and electronic noise at atomic and molecular scales. However, a key quantity of current interest—the thermal conductance of single-molecule junctions—has not yet been directly experimentally determined, due to the enormous challenge of detecting minute heat currents at the picowatt level. Through the research in this project we were able to demonstrate that picowatt-resolution scanning probes that we had pioneered previously to study the thermal conductance of single-metal-atom junctions, when used in conjunction with a time-averaging measurement scheme to increase the signal-to-noise ratio, also allowed quantification of the much lower thermal conductance of single-molecule junctions. Our experiments on prototypical Au–alkanedithiol–Au junctions containing various length molecules with two to ten carbon atoms confirmed that the thermal conductance is to a first approximation independent of molecular length, consistent with detailed ab initio simulations. The thermal conductance of the measured junctions exhibits a nearly length-independent behavior with a value of approximately 20 pW/K, furthermore suggesting that thermal transport in single-molecule junctions is ballistic. We anticipate that our approach will broadly enable systematic exploration of thermal transport in many other one-dimensional systems, such as short molecules and polymer chains, for which computational predictions of thermal conductance have remained experimentally inaccessible. Details of this work can be found in a Nature publication at https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-019-1420-z.
